body: oh, just saw this @fkiraly https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2942, can we use this issue instead?

>1. Where to put the rotation forest and the continue interval tree classifiers. These are standard vector classifiers, not time series classifiers, used within time series classifiers. I think we should just locate them within the file containing the time series classifier of interest.

These are `sklearn` compatible classifiers, correct?
So, I would put them into a `classification_sklearn` dir, and ensure we have tests in there which run the `sklearn` `check_estimator` on the classifiers.

> 2. clustering_experiments and classification_experiments are central to how we run experiments. These are moving to an sktime-estimator-evaluation sub package (still private at the moment).

Instead of doing that, please make sure you align with the benchmarking workstream. You have committed to write benchmarking code for classifiers in 2019 https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/12, which you haven't done.

There is a current benchmarking workstream via GSoC, an now I'm hearing this for the first time, you are again cooking your own things and trying to move things out of the `sktime` package.

Please work with the rest of the community, `sktime` is not just your own research group, and benchmarking time series classifiers is not just your turf.

> My goal is to have this done by the time the grant starts.

As [per the CC decision on May 31](https://github.com/sktime/community-org/blob/main/community_council/previous_meetings/20220531-meeting.md), you are not going to split `sktime` into multiple packages, or work on benchmarking in separation from community led workstreams, since this does not have express approval by the sktime community. Please acknowledge that.

> oh, just saw this @fkiraly https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2942, can we use this issue instead? 

Sure. Closing this as duplicate of #2942.

issue.title: [ENH] cleaning up the `_contrib` folder

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

labels.name: refactor
labels.description: Restructuring without changing its external behavior. Neither fixing a bug nor adding a feature.

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
There apparently is a `_contrib` folder in `sktime` which currently has eclectic experimental content.
We need to refactor it into the correct locations and avoid putting more things into it.

Good first issue, most of these seem like smaller refactor tasks. If taking, please say which of the sub-tasks you would like to work on.

Suggested actions:

- [ ] `clustering` - plotting functionality for clustering. Move to `sktime.clustering` module.
- [ ] `datasets` - duplication of `sktime.datasets`. https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3518
- [ ] `diagram_code` - critical difference diagrams. https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3519
- [ ] `distance_based` looks like a time series classifier. Move to `classification`.
- [ ] `windows_installation` - install instructions. Move to docs, sub-page of install instructions.
- [ ] `_classification_test_reproduction` - tests, should move to `TestAllClassifiers` or `TestAllEarlyClassifiers`, duplications removed
- [ ] `_plot_path` - plotting functionality for alignment. Move to `sktime.alignment` module.
- [ ] `classifier_capabilities_table` - could go in the docs, next to the estimator table
- [ ] `set_classifier`, `set_clusterer`. Not sure why needed, but if needed should be refactored so there is not a million if/else but refs are by class name string. Parameter settings could to into `get_test_params`.
- [x] `ShapeletTransform` - transformer, move to `sktime.transformations`

body:
@fkiraly clustering_experiments and classification_experiments use the benchmarking package. The files are just how we use the classification benchmarking functions in our experiments locally and on our cluster.

This new repository is for us to use sktime in our experiments and store results, not part of the sktime/turing group. There is a reason these files are in a private folder not used by anyone else pretty much.

reopened to respond to comments. 
_"clustering_experiments and classification_experiments are central to how we run experiments. These are moving to an sktime-estimator-evaluation sub package (still private at the moment).
Instead of doing that, please make sure you align with the benchmarking workstream. You have committed to write benchmarking code for classifiers in 2019 https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/12, which you haven't done."_

I may have misunderstood, are you trying to dictate how we run experiments or dictate my workstream? Do you also want to preapprove any papers we write? No, I haven't worked on the benchmarking module, nor has anyone else afaik. Sadly, there are many things I wanted to do but haven't. 

_"As [per the CC decision on May 31](https://github.com/sktime/community-org/blob/main/community_council/previous_meetings/20220531-meeting.md), you are not going to split sktime into multiple packages, or work on benchmarking in separation from community led workstreams, since this does not have express approval by the sktime community. Please acknowledge that."_

this is an open source package right? I am not splitting anything, this was on your express command to get rid of contrib. Are you really saying you want to have approval of how I use sktime? I'll take sktime out of the name of any associated packages if you want, but I dont think you have the right to dictate what github packages I create and what open source code I import into them! 

"Please work with the rest of the community, sktime is not just your own research group, and benchmarking time series classifiers is not just your turf"

I think that such rude and confrontational posts are undesirable, please desist

@TonyBagnall, I think you misunderstand. There is no element of "dictating". You are in the process of making major changes to + `sktime`, and we have rules for that.

* you need to talk to other people working on the same things. You can't just force your changes through. Please open issues that describe your desired changes, open a STEP if they are major. This is the basic process everyone is following.
* There is not, to use your own words, "your workstream". As you say, this is an open source package, so you do not "own" parts of it. Please engage with core developers outside your research team at UEA.

> I think that such rude and confrontational posts are undesirable, please desist

I'm sorry if you find the tone harsh. This is not an easy conversation though, since you are trying to make changes without engaging with the rest of the community. So I understand it might feel confrontational.

But, all I'm asking is, please talk to other people in `sktime`, make sure major changes to it are aligned, and follow the rules that apply to everyone. That's not asking for much, it is insiting on the basic rules of our community.

> I am not splitting anything

You are saying in multiple places that you are going to move out stuff into some package that I heard of first time here, in your first post! This:

> These are moving to an sktime-estimator-evaluation sub package (still private at the moment).

From the first post.
You can't do this without writing a STEP, ok?

We also have a benchmarking workstream, google summer of code, multiple contributors who are not in your research group. We have the developer days next week. You chose to not engage with anyone, not to participate or contribute to the developer event. That is not nice, not very welcoming and not in line with the open source ethos.

Now, in addition, you are trying force your own thing through, with some idea of "moving things out of sktime". That is not ok! Please stop.

> @fkiraly clustering_experiments and classification_experiments use the benchmarking package. The files are just how we use the classification benchmarking functions in our experiments locally and on our cluster.

@MatthewMiddlehurst, if you allow me to say this: I find this really odd that you have code that is specific to Tony's research group, in `sktime`. And, that you are trying to move it out, now of all times, where we have summer projects that mean to make benchmarking easy to use.

Benchmarking classifiers and forecasters is a functionality that I'm sure a lot of users would want to see.
It is something I have also repeatedly suggested you make available to general users of `sktime`.

Why are you not moving it into a form so everyone can use it easily? Not just Tony's research team?

Why are you now, that we have people working on benchmarking, trying to move it out of `sktime` into some private location in Tony's research group? Instead of working with those who try to bring this functionality to everyone in the world?

> I dont think you have the right to dictate what github packages I create and what open source code I import into them!

Of course not. What we are talking about though, is something different - your "right" to do things to `sktime` without engaging with the rest of the community, which you do *not* have.

I am unsure if you have actually read the files you are making this fuss about. `classification_experiments.py` is essentially two versions of this:

```
if __name__ == "__main__":
        print(" Local Run")
        data_dir = "../datasets/data/"
        results_dir = "./temp/"
        cls_name = "FreshPRINCE"
        classifier = FreshPRINCE()
        dataset = "UnitTest"
        resample = 0
        tf = False
        predefined_resample = False

        load_and_run_classification_experiment(
            overwrite=True,
            problem_path=data_dir,
            results_path=results_dir,
            cls_name=cls_name,
            classifier=classifier,
            dataset=dataset,
            resample_id=resample,
            build_train=tf,
            predefined_resample=predefined_resample,
        )
```

This is literally just calling a function from the benchmarking package. We keep them in contrib to avoid having an unnecessary main method in the benchmarking module. What is it you want to keep.
